meta.title: The Art and Science of Penetration Testing: A Guide for Beginners
meta.author: Dr. Patrick Jeff

parts.title: Overview of Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking
parts.body: Penetration Testing is about learning computer security with a focus on hacking tools and even creating hacking setups. This book is designed to let beginners understand the basics of ethical hacking using tools like Kali and Backtrack Linux. It emphasizes learning step by step, moving from one task to another on a DIY "target network." With this, it shows why penetration testing is more than just finding problems, as it involves legally trying to exploit a system and how ethical hackers, or "white hats," aim to secure systems by thinking like attackers, contrasting them with "black hats" who have malicious intent.

parts.title: Hacking Lab Setup & Pen Testing Overview
parts.body:
Lab Setup and Testing Process Overview

When setting up a hacking lab, the key is isolation to practice safely. For newcomers, creating a sandboxed environment by disconnecting from the Internet is crucial. Using VMs has advantages: they're portable and easy to reset. Within a lab setup, using tools on Kali or Backtrack aids in penetration testing this book covers. Labs should have at least an attacker machine (your Kali or Backtrack VM) and targets like Metasploitable and unpatched Windows XP for exploration of vulnerabilities. It's essential to maintain a separate network environment to prevent unauthorized access, keeping any attacks contained.

Overview of Methodology and Best Practices

Pen testing involves a series of methodical steps: Reconnaissance, Scanning, Exploitation, and Post-Exploitation. These steps are vital, ordered processes—skipping ahead can lead to missed opportunities. In recon, gather target data extensively–the more, the better. Following scanning, aims to find open ports and their vulnerabilities. The exploitation phase follows, aiming for administrator access either locally or remotely. Post-exploitation involves making access more persistent if necessary. Essential is also reporting findings clearly. While vulnerability scanners aid learning, reliance on them can hinder skill development beyond the basics.
